meaning_mnemonic:
The <radical>king</radical> will send his men with <radical>sword</radical>s into your <radical>private</radical> <radical>rice paddy</radical> if you come across <kanji>lapis lazuli</kanji>. Even though this is your private land, he wants that lapis lazuli to make some new crowns and thrones for himself. Plus he's the king, so he can do whatever he wants.

If you've never taken an art history class (or played Minecraft) you may never have come across lapis lazuli, but think of it as a pretty, blue precious stone that people really, really liked in the olden days.
reading_mnemonic: You run up and ask how this <kanji>lapis lazuli</kanji> thievery isn't illegal and one of the swordsmen just shouts, "<reading>Loo</reading>phole (る)!" What? What loophole? What law says that the king gets to steal your stuff?

meaning_mnemonic: There are <radical>stone</radical>s that smell like <radical>trash</radical> in the <radical>river</radical>. You reach in and realize these rocks are made of <kanji>sulfur</kanji>. Even the flow of this water can't hide the stink of these sulfur rocks.
reading_mnemonic: You throw the <kanji>sulfur</kanji> rock as hard as you can, but it hits someone in the back of the head. Oh no, it's <reading>Ryu</reading> (りゅう) from Street Fighter. You try to apologize and explain that you just didn't want this stinky trash rock, I mean, sulfur rock near you. You didn't know he was there.

meaning_mnemonic: If you spill something <radical>red</radical> on yourself in <radical>winter</radical> you should <kanji>pardon</kanji> yourself immediately and try to find something else to wear. It's very dangerous to wear red in winter, and even if it seems rude, make sure you pardon yourself right away and get that taken care of!
reading_mnemonic: If you don't <kanji>pardon</kanji> yourself fast enough the winter <reading>sha</reading>man (しゃ) will burst in and cast a spell on you, taking away all the clothes that have red on them! Now you have to pardon yourself for being naked!

meaning_mnemonic: You see <radical>seven</radical> <radical>sword</radical>s just sitting in a <radical>hole</radical> and so you decide to <kanji>steal</kanji> them. They were just left in that hole after all, it's not like anyone was using them. And even if they were, they'll never know you were the one to steal them, right?
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>steal</kanji> the swords and realize they aren't just seven random swords, they're from the famous sword <reading>sets</reading> (せつ) they sell online. This particular set is from the Seven Samurai movie. Yes! What a great steal!

meaning_mnemonic: Deep in your <radical>soul</radical>, you feel like you want to pull your <radical>fang</radical>s out by the <radical>root</radical>, but instead you let out a loud <kanji>sigh</kanji>. You're one of the only people you know that has fangs, and it weighs heavily on your soul.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>sigh</kanji> again and say, "I wish I was just a normal <reading>guy</reading> (がい)." I swear the rest of me is a guy like the rest of you. *sigh*

meaning_mnemonic: Put your <radical>fingers</radical> on your <radical>husband</radical> to <kanji>aid</kanji> him. There's something about a spouse's touch that just makes you feel better. Have you ever had someone rub your back while you were hurt or sick or sad? It's nice, right?
reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately, your husband wouldn't need your <kanji>aid</kanji> if he wasn't such a <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ). He walks into doors, he falls down the stairs, he touches the plate when the waiter says it's hot. And every single time your fool husband hurts himself, you aid him.

meaning_mnemonic: Throw a <radical>drunkard</radical> in a cage with a <radical>tiger</radical> and some <radical>spikes</radical> and the tiger will have the time of its life <kanji>play</kanji>ing with them! Think of all the tiger play time possibilities!
reading_mnemonic: If you aren't the tiger, watching it <kanji>play</kanji> is a little like watching someone's head get cut off with a <reading>gui</reading>llotine (ぎ). In fact, you don't want to watch it play at all anymore.

meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>tsunami</radical> gets into a <radical>net</radical> that's im<radical>prison</radical>ing a bunch of <radical>insect</radical>s, the insects are going to get all <kanji>muddy</kanji>. The net gets dragged along with the tsunami water and the insects can't escape, so they just get covered in the yucky stuff.
reading_mnemonic: Unfortunately for the insects, these <kanji>muddy</kanji> conditions have created the perfect habitat for <reading>duck</reading>s (だく). And muddy insects already imprisoned in a muddy net is a duck's favorite treat!

meaning_mnemonic: You're walking down the street when you see <radical>twenty</radical> <radical>big</radical> <radical>cross</radical>es lined up in front of you. Crosses creep you out and this is way too many for you to keep walking so you decide to <kanji>run</kanji> as fast as you can to get past them.
reading_mnemonic: You figure since you're already on the <kanji>run</kanji> that you might as well <reading>hone</reading> (ほん) your running skills while you make your way down this scary, cross lined street.

meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>triceratops</radical> standing in front of a full <radical>moon</radical> and you can't help but see a really strong <kanji>resemblance</kanji>. The triceratops has that round frill thing behind its horns and it looks just like the round full moon. Who knew that a triceratops would resemble the moon!
reading_mnemonic: The first person to see this <kanji>resemblance</kanji> was the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう). That's why he decided to put a triceratops head with the moon behind it on his mon (family crest). Now he's known as the full moon dinosaur shogun, and he's very famous.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tree</radical> is stuck in a <radical>prison</radical> under the <radical>ground</radical> and it's starting to <kanji>rot</kanji> and <kanji>decay</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: You get close to the <kanji>rot</kanji>ting tree and see some rotten <reading>cu</reading>cumbers (きゅう) hanging from its branches. No!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>samurai</radical> puts his <radical>forehead</radical> on the <radical>table</radical> next to his <radical>weapon</radical>. He is just a <kanji>husk</kanji> of his former self. This <kanji>shell</kanji> of a samurai has nothing left.
reading_mnemonic: The only way to bring a <kanji>husk</kanji> of a samurai back to life is to have a <reading>cock</reading> (かく) crow right in his ear.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>receive</radical> radical and <kanji>receive</kanji> kanji are exactly the same.
reading_mnemonic: The best place to <kanji>receive</kanji> anything is in <reading>きょう</reading>と. The city is famous for the quality of everything they make, so if you’re in きょうと, keep your fingers crossed that you’ll receive something.

meaning_mnemonic: You have to reach a certain <radical>number</radical> of <radical>flowers</radical> and <radical>tsunami</radical>s hits to become a legitimate <kanji>fiefdom</kanji>. At least in the old days. If you don't meet one of these conditions, like if you get hit by tsunamis all the time but you only have two or three flowers that will grow, you can't be your own fiefdom.
reading_mnemonic: The most famous <kanji>fiefdom</kanji> checker is <reading>Han</reading> (はん) Solo. He takes his Millennium Falcon and swoops around checking for flowers and signs of past tsunamis and then he'll either say you can or cannot be your own fiefdom. Thanks Han Solo!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>sweet</radical> <radical>woman</radical> sits under a <radical>tree</radical> and works as a <kanji>mediator</kanji>. If you're having a fight with someone, bring them to the sweet woman under the tree and she'll mediate for the two of you. Problem solved! Thanks sweet lady!
reading_mnemonic: You go to pay the woman for being your <kanji>mediator</kanji> for you two but she just says, "<reading>Bye</reading> ばい)." You try to hand her some money and she stares into your eyes. "Bye." Oh... okay, bye then.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>husband</radical> was wearing his <radical>cleat</radical>s when he accidentally stepped on a <radical>bird</radical>. Luckily this particular bird is a <kanji>chicken</kanji>, and chickens are really durable!
reading_mnemonic: The only way to stop the <kanji>chicken</kanji> from putting on your husband's cleats and stepping on him to death in revenge is to feed it the <reading>ca</reading>ke (けい) you were making.

meaning_mnemonic: If you want to take a <radical>flag</radical> out of the <radical>mouth</radical> of a <radical>mantis</radical> you have to make a formal <kanji>request</kanji> first. Mantises don't like to just give things away, and they're kind of mean so if you try to steal the flag it will probably bite you. So make a formal, polite request if you want it.
reading_mnemonic: After you <kanji>request</kanji> the mantis give you its flag it <reading>shock</reading>s (しょく) you by actually spitting it out of its mouth at your feet. You didn't think your request would work, or even if the mantis understood human speech, but it shocked you by doing exactly what you asked!

meaning_mnemonic: When your <radical>scooter</radical> has a <radical>fault</radical>, you need to get an <kanji>alternate</kanji>. Hopefully your insurance will cover it too.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>alternate</kanji> scooter is made entirely of <reading>鉄</reading> (てつ). It's hard and cold and not very comfortable when you sit on it. That's why you chose to keep it as an alternate and not as your everyday scooter.

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>tree</radical> <radical>turkey</radical> has been sitting directly on your <kanji>spine</kanji> for weeks straight. The pain is starting to become unbearable, and it seems like no one wants to help you.
reading_mnemonic: Just as your <kanji>spine</kanji> seems to be getting used to the pressure, the tree turkey unleashes a cry: "<reading>TWEE</reading>T (つい)!" To your horror, a flock of tree turkeys emerge from the trees.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>building</radical> <radical>clown</radical> is the only clown allowed to <kanji>accompany</kanji> you. You hate all clowns, and so does the rest of your town. But this clown is really good at building buildings, and he's allowed to leave his part of town and accompany you while you fix buildings together.
reading_mnemonic: He can only <kanji>accompany</kanji> you for so long though and soon it's time to say <reading>bye</reading> (ばい) again.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>clown</radical> takes a <radical>knife</radical> and <kanji>divide</kanji>s himself. First he divides himself into two pieces, then he's in four pieces, then... oh why won't he stop?!
reading_mnemonic: The clown finally stops trying to <kanji>divide</kanji> himself, and you can't stand to look at all of him. You grab a <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう) ball and bowl all of his divided parts over!

meaning_mnemonic:
If you <radical>say</radical> the <radical>lineup</radical> of your family members that have lived on this earth under the <radical>sun</radical>, you're really explaining your <kanji>genealogy</kanji>.

This kanji has a second meaning too. It means score, as in a musical score or sheet music. So if your sheet music <radical>say</radical>s the <radical>line up</radical> of chords, especially <radical>sun</radical>nny notes, that's the <kanji>score</kanji> of a song. Those sunny notes are loved by your ancestors.
reading_mnemonic: If you can't tell the difference between your <kanji>genealogy</kanji> and a musical <kanji>score</kanji>, you're a <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ) and I can't help you. You aren't a fool, are you? You know the difference.

meaning_mnemonic: You can only manage to avoid a <radical>tsunami</radical> by standing <radical>above</radical> it on a <radical>small</radical> <radical>stool</radical> if you are very <kanji>graceful</kanji>. If you aren't graceful enough the tsunami will knock you and the stool over and you'll be swept away like everyone else.
reading_mnemonic: No matter how <kanji>graceful</kanji> you are, the tsunami still <reading>shook</reading> (しゅく) the small stool. That's where your gracefulness came in. The stool shook, but you didn't. You balanced yourself and refused to go down.

meaning_mnemonic: You hoist your <radical>towel</radical> above your <radical>table</radical>, <radical>drop</radical> into the water and <kanji>sail</kanji> away. You turned the towel into an actual sail and you're balancing on top of the table, which is now a boat.
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>sail</kanji> off into the ocean you hear a familiar voice shout out, "Ahoy!" <reading>Han</reading> (はん) Solo calls. He's also got a towel sail, but it's on the Millennium Falcon, which is half-submerged in the water.

meaning_mnemonic: You see a <radical>soul</radical> on a <radical>cross</radical> covered in <radical>flowers</radical> with <radical>shellfish</radical> at its feet and you suddenly <kanji>resent</kanji> them. It's not like you want to be the one up there on the cross, but so many people left flowers and shellfish for them. It should have been you...
reading_mnemonic: You realize you <kanji>resent</kanji> them because it looks like they're having <reading>fun</reading> (ふん). You aren't having fun, and you wanna be! How dare they have fun when you aren't!

meaning_mnemonic: Pour all of your <radical>alcohol</radical> in the <radical>pool</radical> to <kanji>serve</kanji> all your guests at once! They can all help themselves to as much or as little alcohol as they want! What a great idea!
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>serve</kanji> your guests (and yourself) you look over and see <reading>Shaq</reading> (しゃく) also trying to serve them. And by serving I mean getting served because he's throwing them into the pool.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Gambler</radical>s usually only see the <radical>sun</radical> at <kanji>dawn</kanji>. They gamble all day and through the night, and if they leave it's at the crack of dawn to get home, clean up, and then go back. I haven't known a gambler who's seen the sun ... well ever!
reading_mnemonic: If you're up at <kanji>dawn</kanji> you'll also see the <reading>あか</reading>(red) <reading>つき</reading>(moon). The あかつき only happens as the sun comes up at dawn so usually only gamblers see it. But if you get up early, you can see it too!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> does a <radical>dance</radical> on top of the <radical>tree</radical> to show his <kanji>greatness</kanji> to everyone around. If he dances all the way up there on top of the tree, then no one can deny his <kanji>excellence</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: If you don't recognize the leader's <kanji>greatness</kanji> he will throw <reading>ketsu</reading>p (けつ) all over you (it's a special mix of ketchup and catsup). And it's ketsup because it looks like blood. The blood he'll spill if you don't look up and clap at his great dancing.

meaning_mnemonic: This is a <radical>gold</radical> <radical>roof</radical>, <radical>correct</radical>? Better put a <kanji>lock</kanji> on it, then.
reading_mnemonic: The person who put the <kanji>lock</kanji> on the gold roof was none other than... <reading>Joe</reading> (じょう)?!

meaning_mnemonic: If you touch <radical>ice</radical> for too long you'll get <radical>frostbite</radical> and that's a really hard thing to <kanji>endure</kanji>. A lot of people can't, and die. Then again, you managed to endure touching ice long enough to get frostbite in the first place, so maybe this is baby stuff for you.
reading_mnemonic: The best people in the world at being able to <kanji>endure</kanji> the pain are the <reading>shino</reading>bi (しの) ninjas! They train by hanging out in frozen areas all the time and don't complain at all. Maybe if the pain gets to be too much you can go ask them for advice.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>king</radical> <radical>rake</radical>d all the <radical>mountain</radical>s down into flat land so he could see everyone in the kingdom from his castle windows. You should share your <kanji>congratulations</kanji> with him. Now, quick tell him this was a great idea.
reading_mnemonic: The moment you say "<kanji>Congratulations</kanji>!" you've already started to <reading>miss</reading> (みず) those beautiful mountains. But you can't let missing them ruin your congratulations! Don't let the king know!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>flowers</radical> that grow on your <radical>roof</radical> that look like a sleeping <radical>bear</radical> is <kanji>sedge</kanji>. Sedge grow all over the world!
reading_mnemonic: The next time you see a <kanji>sedge</kanji> bite into it. It tastes like <reading>suga</reading>r (すが)! Luckily, it don't taste like bear.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>king</radical> wants you to make a <radical>rocket</radical> that looks <kanji>glassy</kanji>. It won't be very stable, and it probably won't work, but making it glassy and pretty is the only way to make the king approve.
reading_mnemonic: You take the <kanji>glassy</kanji> rocket and try to stuff some thin <reading>reed</reading>s (り) inside to support it. But because it's clear and glassy the king sees them at the last second.
